intro: Galium squalidum, commonly known as stinkweed, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white to greenish-white flowers that are clustered in cymes, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic, and often have a slightly hairy texture. Galium squalidum is often found in moist, disturbed soils in woodland or wetland habitats.
